an6.62:0.3: Knowledge of the Faculties of Persons
an6.62:1.2: At one time the Buddha was wandering in the land of the Kosalans together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants when he arrived at a town of the Kosalans named Daṇḍakappaka.
an6.62:1.3: The Buddha left the road and sat at the root of a tree on the seat spread out.
an6.62:1.4: The mendicants entered Daṇḍakappaka to look for a guest house.
an6.62:2.1: Then Venerable Ānanda together with several mendicants went to the Aciravatī River to bathe.
an6.62:2.2: When he had bathed and emerged from the water he stood in one robe drying his limbs.
an6.62:2.3: Then a certain mendicant went up to Venerable Ānanda, and said to him,
an6.62:2.4: “Reverend Ānanda, when the Buddha declared that Devadatta was
an6.62:2.5: going to a place of loss, to hell, there to remain for an eon, irredeemable, did he do so after wholeheartedly deliberating, or was this just a way of speaking?”
an6.62:2.6: “You’re right, reverend, that’s how the Buddha declared it.”
an6.62:3.1: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened.
an6.62:4.1: “Ānanda, that mendicant must be junior, recently gone forth, or else a foolish, incompetent senior mendicant.
an6.62:4.2: How on earth can he take something that I have declared categorically to be ambiguous?
an6.62:4.3: I do not see a single other individual about whom I have given such whole-hearted deliberation before making a declaration as I did in the case of Devadatta.
an6.62:4.4: As long as I saw even a fraction of a hair’s tip of goodness in Devadatta
an6.62:4.5: I did not declare that he was
an6.62:4.6: going to a place of loss, to hell, there to remain for an eon, irredeemable.
an6.62:4.7: But when I saw that there was not even a fraction of a hair’s tip of goodness in Devadatta
an6.62:4.9: going to a place of loss, to hell, there to remain for an eon, irredeemable.
an6.62:5.1: Suppose there was a sewer deeper than a man’s height, full to the brim with feces,
an6.62:5.2: and someone was sunk into it over their head.
an6.62:5.3: Then along comes a person who wants to help make them safe, who wants to lift them out of that sewer.
an6.62:5.4: But circling all around the sewer they couldn’t see even a fraction of a hair’s tip of that person that was not smeared with feces.
an6.62:5.5: In the same way, when I saw that there was not even a fraction of a hair’s tip of goodness in Devadatta
an6.62:5.7: going to a place of loss, to hell, there to remain for an eon, irredeemable.
an6.62:5.8: If you would all listen, Ānanda, I will analyze the Realized One’s knowledges of the faculties of persons.”
an6.62:6.1: “Now is the time, Blessed One! Now is the time, Holy One!
an6.62:6.2: Let the Buddha analyze the faculties of persons. The mendicants will listen and remember it.”
an6.62:6.3: “Well then, Ānanda, listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”
an6.62:7.1: “Ānanda, when I’ve comprehended the mind of an individual, I understand:
an6.62:7.2: ‘Both skillful and unskillful qualities are found in this individual.’
an6.62:7.3: After some time I encompass their mind and understand:
an6.62:7.4: ‘The skillful qualities of this individual have vanished, but the unskillful qualities are still present.
an6.62:7.5: Nevertheless, their skillful root is unbroken, and from that the skillful will appear.
an6.62:7.6: So this individual is not liable to decline in the future.’
an6.62:7.7: Suppose some seeds were intact, unspoiled, not weather-damaged, fertile, and well-kept. They’re sown in a well-prepared, productive field.
an6.62:7.8: Wouldn’t you know that those seeds would grow, increase, and mature?”
an6.62:7.10: “In the same way, when I’ve comprehended the mind of an individual, I understand …
an6.62:7.15: This individual is not liable to decline in the future …
an6.62:7.16: This is how another individual is known to the Realized One by encompassing their mind.
an6.62:7.17: And this is how the Realized One knows a person’s faculties by encompassing their mind.
an6.62:7.18: And this is how the Realized One knows the future origination of a person’s qualities by encompassing their mind.

an6.62:8.8: Wouldn’t you know that those seeds would not grow, increase, and mature?”

an6.62:8.16: This is how another individual is known to the Realized One …
an6.62:9.1: When I’ve comprehended the mind of an individual, I understand:
an6.62:9.2: ‘Both skillful and unskillful qualities are found in this individual.’
an6.62:9.3: After some time I encompass their mind and understand:
an6.62:9.4: ‘This individual has not even a fraction of a hair’s tip of goodness. They have exclusively dark, unskillful qualities. When their body breaks up, after death, they will be reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.’
an6.62:9.5: Suppose some seeds were broken, spoiled, weather-damaged. They’re sown in a well-prepared, productive field.
an6.62:9.6: Wouldn’t you know that those seeds would not grow, increase, and mature?”
an6.62:9.8: “In the same way, when I’ve comprehended the mind of an individual, I understand …
an6.62:9.11: ‘This individual has not even a fraction of a hair’s tip of goodness. They have exclusively dark, unskillful qualities. When their body breaks up, after death, they will be reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.’ …”
an6.62:10.1: When he said this, Venerable Ānanda said to the Buddha,
an6.62:10.2: “Sir, can you describe three other individuals who are counterparts of these three?”
an6.62:10.4: “Ānanda, when I’ve comprehended the mind of an individual, I understand:
an6.62:10.5: ‘Both skillful and unskillful qualities are found in this individual.’
an6.62:10.6: After some time I encompass their mind and understand:
an6.62:10.7: ‘The skillful qualities of this individual have vanished, but the unskillful qualities are still present.
an6.62:10.8: Nevertheless, their skillful root is unbroken, but it’s about to be totally destroyed.
an6.62:10.9: So this individual is still liable to decline in the future.’
an6.62:10.10: Suppose that there were some burning coals, blazing and glowing. And they were placed on a broad rock.
an6.62:10.11: Wouldn’t you know that those coals would not grow, increase, and spread?”
an6.62:10.13: “Or suppose it was the late afternoon and the sun was going down. Wouldn’t you know that the light was about to vanish and darkness appear?”
an6.62:10.15: “Or suppose that it’s nearly time for the midnight meal. Wouldn’t you know that the light had vanished and the darkness appeared?”
an6.62:10.17: “In the same way, when I’ve comprehended the mind of an individual, I understand …
an6.62:10.22: This individual is still liable to decline in the future …
an6.62:11.1: When I’ve comprehended the mind of an individual, I understand:
an6.62:11.2: ‘Both skillful and unskillful qualities are found in this individual.’
an6.62:11.3: After some time I encompass their mind and understand:
an6.62:11.4: ‘The unskillful qualities of this individual have vanished, but the skillful qualities are still present.
an6.62:11.5: Nevertheless, their unskillful root is unbroken, but it’s about to be totally destroyed.
an6.62:11.6: So this individual is not liable to decline in the future.’
an6.62:11.7: Suppose that there were some burning coals, blazing and glowing. They were placed on a pile of grass or timber.
an6.62:11.8: Wouldn’t you know that those coals would grow, increase, and spread?”
an6.62:11.10: “Suppose it’s the crack of dawn and the sun is rising. Wouldn’t you know that the dark will vanish and the light appear?”
an6.62:11.12: “Or suppose that it’s nearly time for the midday meal. Wouldn’t you know that the dark had vanished and the light appeared?”
an6.62:11.14: “In the same way, when I’ve comprehended the mind of an individual, I understand …
an6.62:11.19: This individual is not liable to decline in the future …
an6.62:12.1: When I’ve comprehended the mind of an individual, I understand:
an6.62:12.2: ‘Both skillful and unskillful qualities are found in this individual.’
an6.62:12.3: After some time I encompass their mind and understand:
an6.62:12.4: ‘This individual has not even a fraction of a hair’s tip of unskillful qualities. They have exclusively bright, blameless qualities. They will become extinguished in this very life.’
an6.62:12.5: Suppose that there were some cool, quenched coals. They were placed on a pile of grass or timber.
an6.62:12.6: Wouldn’t you know that those coals would not grow, increase, and spread?”
an6.62:12.8: “In the same way, when I’ve comprehended the mind of an individual, I understand …
an6.62:12.11: ‘This individual has not even a fraction of a hair’s tip of unskillful qualities. They have exclusively bright, blameless qualities. They will become extinguished in this very life.’
an6.62:12.12: This is how another individual is known to the Realized One by encompassing their mind.
an6.62:12.13: And this is how the Realized One knows a person’s faculties by encompassing their mind.
an6.62:12.14: And this is how the Realized One knows the future origination of a person’s qualities by encompassing their mind.
an6.62:13.1: And so, Ānanda, of the first three individuals one is not liable to decline, one is liable to decline, and one is bound for a place of loss, hell.
an6.62:13.2: And of the second three individuals, one is liable to decline, one is not liable to decline, and one is bound to become extinguished.”
